description: Dispose of plastic waste in the designated plastic recycling bin. Clean and dry plastics before recycling. Avoid mixing with organic or hazardous waste.
environmentalImpact: Plastic waste can persist in the environment for hundreds of years, polluting land and oceans, harming wildlife, and entering the food chain as microplastics.

description: Compost organic waste such as food scraps and yard trimmings. Use a compost bin or deposit in the municipal organic waste collection. Do not mix with plastics or metals.
environmentalImpact: Improper disposal of organic waste leads to methane emissions, a potent greenhouse gas, and can cause water and soil pollution.

description: Place metal waste in the metal recycling bin. Rinse cans and containers before recycling. Large metal items should be taken to a recycling center.
environmentalImpact: Metal waste can leach toxic substances into soil and water. Mining and processing new metals is energy-intensive and polluting.

description: Recycle paper waste in the paper recycling bin. Remove any plastic or metal bindings. Shredded paper should be bagged separately if required by your local facility.
environmentalImpact: Paper waste contributes to deforestation and landfill volume. Decomposing paper in landfills produces methane, a greenhouse gas.

description: Flatten cardboard boxes and place them in the cardboard or paper recycling bin. Remove any plastic, foam, or packing materials before recycling. Keep cardboard dry and clean for effective recycling.
environmentalImpact: Cardboard waste contributes to deforestation and landfill volume. When not recycled, it decomposes in landfills, producing methane, a potent greenhouse gas. Recycling cardboard saves trees, water, and energy.

description: Dispose of glass bottles and jars in the glass recycling bin. Rinse before recycling. Broken glass should be wrapped and placed in general waste if recycling is not available.
environmentalImpact: Glass waste is non-biodegradable and can persist indefinitely. Broken glass poses physical hazards to humans and animals.

description: Take electronic waste (batteries, phones, computers) to a certified e-waste recycling center. Do not dispose of in regular bins.
environmentalImpact: E-waste contains toxic substances like lead and mercury that can contaminate soil and water, harming ecosystems and human health.

description: Hazardous waste (chemicals, paints, medicines) must be taken to a hazardous waste collection facility. Never pour down the drain or throw in regular trash.
environmentalImpact: Hazardous waste can cause severe environmental damage, poisoning water, soil, and air, and posing serious health risks to humans and wildlife.

description: Donate usable clothing and textiles. Otherwise, place in textile recycling bins if available. Avoid sending textiles to landfill.
environmentalImpact: Textile waste in landfills releases greenhouse gases and toxic chemicals from dyes and fibers, polluting soil and water.

description: For items not listed, consult your local waste management authority for proper disposal instructions.
environmentalImpact: Improper disposal of unknown waste types can lead to pollution, resource waste, and harm to ecosystems. Always seek proper guidance.
